comment.author: 22549175@N02
comment._content:
Edward Weston said the negative is the ‘thing’. This image certainly proves the point.

Making the negative the primary object vs. the print is one among many major limitations for a large-format photographer. The limitations are the motivation for creativity, but in a documentary endeavor, there are situations where cropping is necessary.

The photographer intended to have the detracting edges of this scene cropped. More importantly, the foreground, angling up left to right, would have been dodged revealing detail.
The 2/3 rule was used to attain a sense of depth. The re-production of this image with  the light area on top and a dark area on the bottom is subverting depth. Dodging the foreground would enhance the sense of depth. 
People who create images are compelled to do so by the urge to share what they see. They chose subject, light, and vantage point based on an ideal and work the negative to a print that represents that ideal.

Your careless reproduction of this image is a perversion of their ideal - the photographer who took the image is rolling in his/her grave.

Keep it up, you make my work look all the better and remind me to take my negatives when I go.

comment.author: 22549175@N02
comment._content:
A scan will by-pass a bad printing technique, contact or otherwise.
You will have all the data from the negative, but you still have to ‘conduct the symphony’.

A score is made up of notes– in a negative, the notes are degrees of exposed and unexposed silver. The interpretation of the notes is up to the conductor - they struggle with how it should be performed. Most conductors have history as a guide (the composer’s written instructions or a recording).

With an un-attributed negative, there is probably no way to know what the composer had in mind, but perhaps your algorithm can produce an acceptable image.

comment._content:
George,
There is “stuff “ in the upper left corner – that might be  damage. Unlike a 35mm negative that has a border because of sprocket holes, large-format negative edges get handled.
On the right side there is what looks like tree leaves – if so, that was unintentional and should have would have  been cropped.
That is the obvious, the less than obvious:
“With an un-attributed negative, there is probably no way to know what the composer had in mind...”
The extremely less than obvious, except LF photographers, is that the negative is not the print.
“....the notes are degrees of exposed and unexposed silver. The interpretation of the notes is up to the...”  -----printer of the negative.

Bob
